Alrighty, first review. Excuse the (noobishness?) of the review considering i've only really read a few others. Just really wanted to get a review out. So yeah, non non biyori.
So I've never been a huge fan of moe-blob type anime. They're relaxing, fun, comedic and all, but I usually find myself rushing to the final episode without really taking time to appreciate the show itself. But with Non Non Biyori, I found it completely different in the aspect of delivering to the viewer with pure enjoyment. With other moe anime such as Tamako Market, barakamon, usagi drop, and the small part of hidamari sketch thatI did see, it wasn't even on the same spectrum of Non Non Biyori. I never attached myself to the characters as well as I did with this series. They all have distinct personalities, but ones that are not to stressed to the point of unrealisticness. Now to the scoring.


Story: 8


(+) Each individual story in the show has a very distinct objective at the beginning, but can go a completely opposite direction, which actually surprisingly creates some A-class humor imo. 

(+/-) Usually 2-3 different stories in each episode, which for the ones who don't enjoy these types of shows can make the episode feel longer, but for the ones who love it, the lengthening feel of the episodes makes it even more enjoyable

( - ) With the series itself being episodic, you never get a continuous plot.


Art: 10


(+) Beautiful artwork,  bright and colorful backgrounds which adds to the atmosphere of the show.

(+) Animation so good it creates it's own comedic situations

(+) Character design done wonderfully, expressions of characters and their interactions with the world they live in work perfectly together, well done Silver Link animation.



Sound: 9


( - ) Though the music in the show is relaxing and really makes you dwell deep into the show, it's not all to memorable, and is honestly pretty forgettable. And I'm not one to forget good soundtracks.

(+) Outstanding voice casting. All the voices fit quite well, but one single individual comes to mind whenever I think of the voices, and I'm sure it's the same for everyone else as well, Renge. This actually surprises me because I despised Kotori Koiwai's voice acting in Charlotte, which actually made me drop the show after episode 2. But hey, well done this time.

(+) A+ Opening with an exceptional ending song to back it up.


Character: 9


(+) As I said in the beginning of this review, the distinction of the characters are immeasurable to many other anime.

(+) The sound and art aren't the only thing to contribute to the atmosphere to the show. The characters presence and how they react to certain situations make the mood joyous and help connect to the characters in ways unimaginable

( - ) Not a lot of screen time for the twins' brother. Even though he was more of a gag character, I would have really enjoyed a skit or two (not even episode) with him leading the stories main character.


Enjoyment: 9


(+) With the tranquil and calm world that Non Non Biyori has and the lively characters it presents, the show never fails to disappoint a great mix of the two and often results in some unbearably funny situations.

(+) Learning about how the characters live and the situations they encounter along with how they deal with them is overall very enjoyable.

( - ) Only 1 or 2 stories I had no real interest in.


Well there is my first review, hope everyone reading it enjoyed.

Non Non Biyori is a masterclass in slice of life anime. A beautiful, relaxing world awaits for those who step in, as it waits for the audience with open arms and an air of sweet nostalgia.
    Viewers unacquainted with Non Non Biyori would quickly find themselves surrounded by rich earth, wholesome greenery, savoury blue skies, as have I when starting the series. Experiencing the first episode was akin to enjoying hot brewed tea, in that one could go through it at an amiable and relaxed pace, where upon completion, one would feel a sense of tranquility that comeswith drinking some damn good tea. Non Non Biyori strikes me as a competent show that sets and sticks with its pace throughout, evident from the very first episode, with each sequence happening in vignettes.  Also, the relaxing nuance and tone set by its writers was enjoyable and well worthy of praise, hardly have I seen an all girls Slice-of-Life without the crazy and whacky characters getting into dumb antics cause LOL random.


    Further inspection into this show yields greater insights into what makes Non Non Biyori such a fantastic ride through and through.


    We start off with Hotaru, having just moved into the village, she makes new friends with her classmates in her new school. They now go on about their daily lives, experience adventures and have fun in the idyllic mountains. This series captures such instances of their daily lives. As per the slice of life genre, this show lacks an overarching plot and acts merely as an eyepiece to what any character may be up to at any moment of time.


  For most of Non Non Biyori, we find ourselves watching events through the perspective of Hotaru, occasionally with wide-eyed wonder as the new environments hide many surprises. Among the new sights and sounds, we encounter the other main characters of Non Non Biyori as well, with personalities as varied as as the landscapes we see throughout the show. 


Komachi flutters from mature upperclassman to a clumsy and precocious character, while Natsumi, her sister, portrays a carefree, lackadaisical personality that is tempered with occasional ingenuity and common sense. 


Renge is opaque, a brick wall, albeit, an entertaining brick wall, as most six-year olds are, and also my favourite character. Yes I share the same opinion as all other viewers. 


The brother is there as well. 


Hotaru remains neutral, and behind this neutrality hides repressed childlike curiosity and excitement, given that she is twelve years old after all. (Yes, do not let appearances fool you, she is twelve. Because Anime.)


Add in the colourful side characters and this show‘s writers have crafted a powerful, nuanced driving force behind its narrative. It is clear that love was put into creating such a delightful cast, the most important feature in a slice of life anime.

(Yes, this is a long segment. What do you expect? Characters are the quintessential part of Slice of Life anime, with no other grand narrative or ultimate objective to move towards, and the only draw for watchers. No doubt I would allocate a large portion of my word count to elaborating on this aspect of the show. Back to the review.)


  Visually, Non Non Biyori is a treat. Finely painted backdrops of natural environments are prevalent throughout the series, acting as focal points for the current narrative, usually shown through a long pan or still frame, giving the premise a scenic feel. Also let me try out my amateur film analysis here. This director is also fond of zooming in on still objects as a form of cutting between scenes, a technique that helps to maintain immersion for the viewer, and also helping reinforce the message of the show, to “Take life easy.” just as our cast have. Thus, such a technique diverts our attention from the action, just as one strays their eyes when relaxing, fixating attention on something normally of little interest. 


The aesthetic is also bright, cheerful and easy on the eyes as plenty of colours are mixed to give calming hues and add ambience. In terms of character animation, sadly, they are not as intricate or meticulous as the backdrops, but are just as serviceable. 


Character designs are endearing, where Renge’s hair is like an insect and is adorable and her mouth which is always a triangle no matter what is happening and other character quirks that are too cute to handle and………...Well, you get the idea. The characters are all distinct and serve their roles competently. It has a strong “anime” flavour to it, to put bluntly. Still, Kudos to Silver Link Studio here, the way they made their immersive forests, scenic hills and soothing natural environments shows their visual design to be outstanding and well worthy of praise. 

   t made me feel like I had stepped out of my room into beautiful nature, which is nice because I do not leave my room.


  Enjoyment can also be found when listening to its soundtrack. Many of these arrangements sound unique and all carry the same distinct nostalgic flavour. Sound design is also top notch, when immersing viewers in the sounds of the great outdoors: cicadas, the sound of summer heat, cows mooing and so on. Sounds like a quiet village indeed. The opening and ending songs are on point as well, full of personality and life. I do not have much more to say, except that I have the soundtrack on my IPod. It is good.


  All in all, Non Non Biyori understands its role: to provide one with relaxing entertainment, and pushes to do so through engaging storytelling, affable comedy and crafting an immersive, beautiful world.  It is far from a technical masterpiece, yet it does not need to be one, to spark a sense of nostalgia in its audience, welcoming them home with open arms. Non Non Biyori is a work that boasts great accessibility and equally great enjoyment, a must-try for anyone interested in the Slice-of-Life genre.


I gave it all 10s ?

The first thing I've noticed about this anime is the beautiful scenery. Okay, it's moe too, but so is 90% of other slice of life stuff.
Non Non Biyori focuses on lives of four girls who go to the same school, their families and friends. Okay, that's nothing new. We've seen that a thousand times before. But NNB has something that other similar shows don't have. It has... "it". Some charm that makes it enjoyable. I can't describe it; you'd have to watch it to see for yourself.
The girls are all of different age. Yet they all go to the same class because they live inmiddle of nowhere and nobody else goes to the school except them. Well, two of them have an older brother who also goes to their class, but he has very little screen time. In fact, we never even hear him speak?! To make things more interesting, the sisters and their brother have another older sister who's the teacher in their class.\n\n
Like I said, this show is very pleasant to look at. Not only the characters are cute, but the surroundings are beautiful, too. Countryside never looked this pretty. The girls still have fun in their free time, but since they aren't from the city, they don't have fun the way city folks do. It's interesting to see how they make their own fun.\n\n
Okay, like many other SoLs, this isn't very exciting, so if you're looking for action, tension and thrilling scenes, you won't find them here. But if you want to relax and feast your eyes after a hard working day, NNB can be the anime for you. SoL lovers, give it a shot if you already haven't!

Watching Non Non Biyori is like playing the game Animal Crossing. It depicts a quiet, countryside life, has an amazing and relaxing soundtrack, beautiful scenery with calming sounds of nature, cute characters, and just enough humorous dialogue to keep you laughing. However, if you watch it when you're tired, it'll probably relax you so much you'll drift off to sleep.

The story is sort of about some country kids who have moved from Tokyo and are experiencing culture shock with their new environment as most people will, especially at a very young age like these girls are. It's a feel-good series that will brighten your days even if your sad with rare touching moments in it. Not a very original plot with cliched characters.
I don't know why people are so into these characters, they're pretty much your typical whiny kid. The only one I like out of the bunch and is my favorite character is Natsumi, now she was fun to watch but not greatbecause she does get explosive. But the other characters are mediocre, Hotaru is a crybaby, Komari is a know-it-all who hates being called and treated like a little girl. And the youngest girl (I forgot her name but I think it's Rin), rather acts more like an adult than a kid.\n\n
I'm one who doesn't think this needs a sequel because I'm not fond of Non Non Biyori, it was a childish and silly comedy series with some weird elements to it, not surprising for a series aimed at kids but even they might find some of the series' music too babyish. Though, the series is not very very weird but it's still weird. Though, some parts did make me laugh but some jokes fell flat.

Fully immersive and tremendously enjoyable series. Watching Hotaru and her friends live very normal day-to-day lives in their very rural country village is one of the most relaxing and stress-reducing activities that I've come across. Every single scene is rendered beautifully, and will really take you to another dimension.
The artists did an amazing job with setting up the scenes; I found myself wanting to go take walks to nearby parks every time I watched the show. 
There is slow but noticeable character development, but a normal amount that real children would go through in the timespan of the series. All of the characters have distinctpersonalities, and it's so easy to fall in love with every single one.\n\n
After watching this masterpiece, I found myself wanting to go wander around and play like a kid again. Just today I went to a park and (as a 22 year old husky guy) played on the swings to my heart's abandon. Good job, Non Non Biyori, you've made me young again.

This anime is a panacea of the heart and mind.
Life too stressful? Worried or anxious about something? Just sit down in front of the screen and put this anime on, and all your concerns will dissolve away - probably within seconds. Everything - setting, plot, sound, music, art, humour - all of it is perfectly crafted at maximising this effect. And what an effect it is.
The story itself is a simple one. It follows the daily lives of four girls of various ages who all live in the same rural village and are in the same class at school. Almost everything that happens is followingtheir daily lives, with events that are both realistic and completely believable. As far as overarching story goes, that's about it - this isn't an anime you should be watching if you only care for a tense plot full of twists and turns. It is predominantly episodic in nature, although characters and settings are gradually built up over time so there's no lack of progress. Each episode contains one or two stories, every single one of which is a joy to watch and will melt your heart. The humour is lighthearted in tone, and is aimed at adding to this heart-melting effect, rather than at making you laugh out loud, although there are a few moments that could do this as well. There are also a few moments that will invoke other emotions, all very effectively and very naturally.


The cast is focused mainly on the four girls. Komari is the eldest of the four, although you wouldn't know it by looking. She is very self conscious of the fact that she is unusually small for her age and tries to make up for this by attempting (and largely failing) to act grown up. Hotaru, on the other hand, is unusually mature, at least on a physical level, for a fifth grader. She also quickly develops a crush on her cute chibi senpai, although none of the others ever seem to realise it. Natsumi is Komari's younger sister, and is a bit of a layabout. She's too lazy to work hard at anything and is always getting in trouble for one thing or another. And then there's Renge, called "Ren-chon" by Natsumi. I could honestly wax lyrical about Ren-chon all day, but I don't want to bore you any more than I already am, so I'll just say that she's the youngest of the cast, who knows a lot about things that you wouldn't expect a first grade student to know, but otherwise acts fairly normally for her age. Oh, she also has some brilliant facial expressions, and Koiwai Kotori's voice acting of her character is a definite candidate for being the best I've ever come across.

Every member of the supporting cast, just like the main characters, each have their own distinctive but realistic and believable personalities, and are every bit as likeable as the central four cast members.


The humour and characters may be brilliant, but what makes this series really stand out is the music and images. As someone who tends to focus very heavily on the characters of a series, I don't usually care much for these things - as long as they add to the immersement, enjoyment and feel of a series, just about anything's fine by me. But here even I can't help but be overwhelmed. The series starts with nothing but pictures, sound effects and music building up the scene and setting with pure imagery. It's almost 2.5 minutes before anything is actually said, yet by that time you will likely have already entered into a state of total bliss from the gorgeous artwork, more reminiscent of a high budget film or even something you might see in an art gallery than a TV series, and soothing background music and sound effects of what is being shown. And, while the effect may not be as intense in later scenes, the quality does not drop. Just about every background in this entire series is a work of art both literally and figuratively.


I've watched the first episode over and over again and every time the effect is the same. The entire anime is thoroughly rewatchable, and every episode provides the perfect relaxation whether on your first watch or your tenth. Even brilliantly written series that depend on plot twists and reveals often grow dull when watching through for the third time, but that is of no concern for an anime like this.


A lot of slower paced anime, however, require you to be in the right mood before watching them, but again that is of no concern here, as Non Non Biyori will put you in that right mood, no matter what your previous state of mind.


All in all, this is a series to be watched, loved and enjoyed over and over again. Everything is perfectly toned to add to this viewing pleasure as much as possible, and it is indeed a pure pleasure to watch.


If you want to know what nirvana feels like, watch this anime.



tl;dr THIS ANIME IS GAY

Non Non Biyori is an anime that could be described as Relaxing and Very Good for those who are looking for a story away from science fiction and based more on real life.
The story is literally a pure slice of life that shows the occurrences of these four girls in a rural village of Japan for close to a year, each episode has a different main protagonist without following a very defined sequence teaching us that "happiness is based on Have a quiet life without worries. "
The soundtrack is very good, an opening that for my taste is one of the best in the genreof slice of life and an ending with a rather peculiar and striking lyrics. Background sounds go well with every season that passes through the story.\n\n
The characters also very well, each one of them has a different personality that contrasts with the other creating comic situations a little away from the clichés that abound in comedies. Renge is the youngest of the group and who is usually the most perceptive, Hotaru is the new girl who comes to the village having to adapt, Natsumi is the prankster and the one who always wants to have fun at the expense of everyone and Komari is the victim of Jokes about his sister and who arouses the interest of Hotaru.\n\n
If you also like it as much as I see a good slice of life I'm sure that this series will enjoy much, making you remember those times when you were a child and had a life where the biggest concern was choosing to play with your friends.\n
Personally I think that within the genre of Slice of Life is among the best three I have seen.

For a show where nothing of importance happens, I found Non Non Biyori infinitely more entertaining than most anime out there. It's basically a love letter to the slow, dying lifestyle of rural Japan. And yet, the show's characters make their own adventures and manage to have fun every single day. Some episodes are emotional and heartwarming, but the show doesn't hit you over the head with it. Instead, it makes excellent use of comedy without relying on absurd slapstick and cliches. 
My only complaint is that some of the side characters are just as compelling as the main cast, and I would have lovedto see more of them. But overall, this is one of the most relaxing and heartfelt anime I've ever watched. It's great to sit down and binge a few episodes at the end of a long day.\n

にゃんぱす!
At first glance, I don't think it's a well done anime, I don't even have any interest. It was just some weird child. But... at the same time and so on, I feel it's a miraculous job. Who did this?
The artwork seems right, the plot is so natural that makes me jealous. It's real, right? Honestly, I regret that I doubted Non Non Biyori at first sight. It's so enjoyable... the purity of characters, settings, and even the opening track.
So, it's recommended for those who looking for a genuine tranquilty from another side of slice of life without anything artificial.

Non Non Biyori
Art: I absolutely love the art of this show. It is fluid and fresh and looks very new. It is rather interesting that there are so few characters in the show, but each of them are able to be easily distinguished between each other without falling into the stereotypical type casting. The background art is beautiful. The landscape and the countryside really wonderful and the colors are just fantastic. Really this show is about 75% art and scenery. 
Sound/Music: There was quite a bit of direction on this title. Really the music is what drives this show outside of the art. They clearlyknew what they were doing with the sound direction. Having a bit of great music really takes this show to a better place for me. With things that are both fun to look at and nice to listen to it creates an atmosphere that makes me want to get invested into the show.


Story: So, while there isn’t much ‘story’ to this show there is an overall plot, while it is pretty bare. What I could assume to be the main character, Hotaru, comes in to the country from the city and joins a class of four students, all different grades, in a single room. This then leads to the group becoming fast friends and over the course of the year that the story takes place, they go through all sorts of experiences together. 


Personal Reflection: I really enjoy story when it comes to shows. While this show doesn’t have much of that, it has beautiful art and wonderful music. My gripe is that there was really no story. I wanted to be able to get invested into the characters, but I felt that they were pretty 2-dimensional, one didn’t even have a single line the entire series! And that made it really hard to enjoy the show. Sure it isn’t a bad show by any means, but to me, i felt that it fell short in a way that I would not recommend it. If you like little-to-no plot and cute characters than go for it, anything else, this might be a pass for you.


Overall Score: 6.5/10

This anime is one of the diamonds among the coal of slice-of-life. At first glance it seems like a typical, semi-boring slice-of-life anime about cute girls with cute dresses and cute houses, doing cute things. Seen it, tired of it... But wait! That's not just what this show is about at all! Yes, it's about the everyday life of four cute girls living in the countryside, but if you're looking for a relaxing and funny anime that will get your mind of everything else, look no further. This anime is the very definition of a slice-of-life masterpiece and you will not regret watching it ifyou like that genre. 


Story 9/10: As mentioned, this is a story about four girls of different ages living on the countryside. It has a captivating story without even trying. Even though the girls do things they consider normal, people that don't live in the countryside will find an amusing story, and those who live in the countryside will find a charming representation of what it's like, filled with moments that makes you smile and giggle. Some may find that boring, but not me. It doesn't have one single storyline, but many small happenings in the young girls' lives, and not a single episode is the same. 


Art 10/10: I am a sucker for good art. Even though the art in this anime is the typical moe artstyle, it doesn't make this anime any less good. In fact, it really fits the rest of the art and makes the characters personalities shine. And, oh the scenery! Beautiful, country scenery with the mountains, the trees and the rice fields. This anime also perfects the use of breathing pauses that lets the animation do the talking. There are several minute long scenes that can be just a character badly playing a recorder, landscape shots or waiting for a reaction, and they all work really well. It gives the viewer a chance to breathe and relax. Together it makes an absolutely gorgeous anime filled with small "wow" moments. 


Sound 10/10: After this anime, I had to search for the OST online at once. This soundtrack is filled with both quick and fun music and relaxing orchestra. It has a lot of outstanding tracks and really helps make the anime shine. The OP is a song by the one and only nano.RIPE. It's catchy and likable and fits very well with the mood of the anime. The same can be said about the ED, which is sung by the four main characters voice actors. 


Character 9/10: Though this anime had some anime cliches, like the tsundere loli, this anime has a very good character cast. The main cast consists of Komari, who is a tsundere and very childish, despite wanting to be adult-like, Natsumi, who is very lazy and loves pranks, Hotaru, who is responsible, but amusingly obsessed with a certain character, and Renge, an easily impressed, easily fascinated, weird and adorable kid. There's also the brother that never gets a line, the delinquent-like, but secretly kind Candy-Store and Nee-nee the lazy teacher/big sister (These are not actually their names, it's just what the kids call them). All the characters fit so well in the story and, even if some are cliches, it doesn't make the anime cliche. Each character is still very much it's own character and gives of a fun, likable and unique personality that fits the anime perfectly. They're funny, happy and sometimes amusingly over-the-top, especially Natsumi and Renge, who by the way is the cutest little thing on this planet.


Enjoyment 10/10: There's a reason this anime made it on my top five list of favorite anime. It's fun, relaxing and adorable, and it's just so darn likable. It's the perfect anime for a slice-of-life lover like myself. I found myself always looking forward to the next episode every week, even if it didn't have any long storyarcs, cliffhangers or a single storyline to follow. It is simply an enjoyable set of the everyday happenings of these four young girls. 


Overall 9/10: This is one of the most likable and lovable anime out there. it's relaxing, pleasing to both the eyes and ears, and filled with a fun and exiting character cast. The only thing that I can comment on is the fact that it has a lot of anime characters cliches and moe, something that can put people off, and the story can get boring to people that are not into everyday happenings in anime, but don't be fooled! It's definitely worth the watch! 


If you like action and drama-filled anime, this is not for you, but if you're a fan of slice of life and comedy and like or tolerate the moe art, this is your diamond. Even if you're an all-rounder like me, who likes most genres, you're probably gonna love this anime.

Non Non Biyori is just so cute, watching it is like being in a relaxing daydream. This stands above other slice of life anime due to its realism, pacing and lack of stereotyped behaviour. Some gags might involve the characters standing still and nothing happening for 10 seconds or more and it has a certain real life charm that really fits in with the countryside theme. The characters are also really unique and individual with no stereotyped "loli" or "moe" behaviour. Ren-chon is so cute and realistic almost to a Miyazaki level of adorable, and it's hard not to compare this to Totoro and someof the other sleepier Ghibli films.\n\n
This is one of my favourite anime, ever since Shirokuma Cafe ended I've been waiting for something just as charming and adorable and I was very happy to see this. I'd love to see more episodes, I think this would be awesome to watch alongside Aku no Hana... you could alternate between the light and dark sides of countryside living to get two unique perspectives of this type of living.

First review, please don't hurt me ;w;
Non Non Biyori is one of the best slice of life animes I've ever seen, and probably the best anime for the latter half of 2013. It offers everything you usually expect from a slice of life - comedy, relaxation, some more emotional moments - basically, LIFE at its finest. But let's start from the beginning.
Non Non Biyori tells the story of four girls living in the country. Ichijou Hotaru, a fifth-grader from Tokyo had to move out due to her parents' work duties. The school in the country isn't exactly what she expected - together with her thereare only 5 students, each one from a different year. There she meets the rest of our lovely main cast:\n
 - Miyauchi Renge (or Ren-chon), a seven year old girl with great imagination,\n
- Koshigaya Komari (or Koma-chan), an eight-grader with a height complex and the yuri love interest of Hotarun,\n
- Koshigaya Natsumi (or Nattsun), the younger, energetic sister of Komari.\n
The fifth student is Koshigaya Suguru, the older brother of Komari and Natsumi who actually never gets to say a thing - it's a running gag. There's also room for a few side characters - my personal favorite was Kagayama Kaede, referred to by the rest of the girls as "Candy Store".\n
You get to see a lot of funny situations they are encountering - there are of course your mandatory summer/winter/New Year/school festival episodes, however, they are made quite differently, so you won't get a deja vu. Take the school festival as an example - remember there only are 5 students, and you should get the idea. Overall the story was handled masterfully - all slice of life series should look like NNB.\n
As for the art - I had no bigger remarks. It looked just like the rest of modern animes, luckily there was no 3D art (which I despise in anime). The backgrounds were created with a lot of detail - I assume the location the anime takes place in was based on an original place, because there is always a photo of a landscape at the end of each episode. You get to see a lot of wonderful, detailed places that just feel natural - a lot of it is shown in Episode 1. My personal favorite moment was at the end of the first episode, when the main cast approached a cherry tree - it was a great part. As for character designs, they were good, but sometimes you could notice a minor flaw.\n
I really liked the soundtrack and voicing for this anime. The music gives a peaceful, almost lazy vibe - a perfect example would be when Renge plays on her recorder for a longer while, walking down a road. I wasn't a big fan of the opening, but the ending, sung by the 4 main seiyuus was very enjoyable and silly. As for the voices, the seiyuus did a very good job, it wasn't above the usual standards though. Renge's voice was funny and memorable -  I'm not going to forget the "Nyanpasu!" she greets everyone with, miss Koiwai Kotori who voiced her did a great job.\n
All of the characters were lovable - Hotarun's silly ideas about Komari, Komari's puberty shenanigans, Nattsun's laid-back attitude or Renge's childishness were a lot of fun to watch and couldn't be possibly developed better. The side characters also deliver - they're funny and memorable, Candy Store and Renge's sister, who is also a teacher in their school were the best. I feel that the running joke of Suguru being silent was overused and we should have at least gotten a short sentence from him in the last episode.\n
Overall, I really, really enjoyed Non Non Biyori and will try to recommend it to anyone looking for a good slice of life series. There's just a certain feeling about this anime that makes you think about it and miss it more and more. The over 20 minute-long episodes pass like a few seconds and you really crave for more. I will be impatiently waiting for the OVA and hope for another season.

It's pretty incredible to watch this all over again. Coincidentally enough, I watched Non Non Biyori 3 months ago on this day, so that's really neat.
 The girls, Renge-chon, Natsume, Koma-chan and Hotaru are fantastic. Renge is fantastic throughout the entire anime, her monotone-like voice and facial expressions are amazing and make for great comedy. Natsume and Koma-chan are really cute sisters, I think it's unique and interesting how Koma-chan, the older sister is shorter and looks more like an imouto, it makes for really funny scenarios. Hotaru; the really developed 5th grader who moved from Tokyo is great too, her perspective on living inthe country and how the rest of the girls are intruiged by it is funny.


 The support characters are great too, Candy Store was such a huge surprise when I originally watched NNB, seeing her again was fantastic. Episode 10, when we see the flashback of Candy Store and Renge together and the day ended with them both sleeping together; overwhelmed by feels. Seeing Renge and Candy Store in the current time and day also fall asleep together was just amazing. Candy Story is most definitely a surprise and a phenomenal character. The sensei, or Nee-nee is pretty great too, she's a grown up Renge and it's just so good. The other supporting characters, like Hikagi, Renge's older sister, Konomi and such, all really good, great cast of girls.


 Can't forget about Nii-chan either, he never says a word and is like an enigma, but he somehow manages to be funny and a great addition to the cast anyhow, no idea why, but it's great.


 The episode with Renge and Honoka was fantastic; even though Renge doesn't have many facial expressions, when we see Renge standing at Honoka's grandparents door, being told that Honoka had to leave yesterday, was so hard. Renge just stands there for a good long minute until it hits her that her friend has left. 


 One of the best things that Non Non Biyori does, compared to most slice of life cute shows I've seen is, there are clear episodes from the beginning which set up the characters. They all have episodes dedicated to them and it really feels like you get to know them on a personal level, huge compliment to NNB for doing that.


 The OP, having to listen to it again just brings in such a rush of feelings. It's somehow nostalgic, even though it's only been 3 months since I've seen it. It's also one of the greatest OP's ever and I love the song entirely. The ED is also fantastic and just a feel good song entirely.The music in NNB is also fantastic. If you've ever wondered if an anime can use music in a meaningful way, especially in a slice of life show, NNB pulls it off so well. The recorder that Renge plays is used throughout the entire anime for BGM, it's so good. There are many great compositions to listen to through the 12 episodes. All the music is so goooood.. An OST worth owning.


 The art style doesn't need any explanation, neither does the animation. It's fantastic and absolutely beautiful, well drawn and well animated, watching Non Non Biyori is one of the most pleasant things you can do, without a doubt.


 Still one of my favorite anime I have ever seen, with each episode being well directed and having a bundle of laughs. It's really just perfection in my eyes and with Non Non Biyori Repeat already airing, more greatness to come!

Like many people have already said, Non Non Biyori is a great way to cheer up when you're emotionally down or relax when you are all stressed out. The show is a pure joy to watch. 
STORY: 8.5-9/10
You actually get what the show is from the synopsis, there isn't something else hidden for you to discover while watching it. Cute kids playing and fooling around in the countryside. Yeah, Non Non Biyori is a pure Slice Of Life anime and for some this might seem boring. Actually it isn't boring at all, at least in my opinion. Every episode is a new adventure, which takesplace in a different  location and from episodes to episodes in different seasons as well. Even though the events are quite simple and basic, they are well made and quite original. But the best part of each episode is how goofy and funny it can get. I loved the comedy and the creativity in this anime. Everything was colourful, cute, bright, innocent and childlike, but not childish. Even if the show can be surely watched by babies as well, it's not a children's show where the protagonists count numbers and spell the alphabet. It can be watched by everyone because it doens't contain any hard, inappropriate, violent or obscure meaning. And that's the magic with Non Non Biyori. No matter how you feel, or how old you are, you have fun. 


ART: 9/10

It's beautiful, the character designs are excellent, the backgrounds are gorgeous and the colouring is very vibrant.


SOUND: 8/10

Perfect match for the anime. It doesn't stand out but it has some very interesting tracks that create a very relaxing atmosphere. The only thing I don't like is the opening singer, she is bad in my opinion, but who cares?


CHARACTERS: 10/10

The best part of the anime. Each character stands out and the main cast together is the most cute and hilarious thing ever. What I loved the most about the main characters is how real their friendship feels, besides their age difference. Having kids from different age groups hanging out is rare in real life unfortunately. That might actually be the only meaning Non Non Biyori has to offer. A cover doesn't necessarily defines the book itself, we all have a child within us and everyone can offer us something special, besides how old they are. These 3 things that are present in every episode of the show touched me actually.


ENJOYMENT: 10/10 

The feeling I felt while watching Non Non Biyori is exactly like the feeling of happiness I feel when I wake up and look at the sky and it's crystal clear. I can only give this feeling a 10.


OVERALL: 9/10

Actually even a 10, that's always the toughest part. I'll need some time to decide for sure. I think this anime can be watched almost by everyone, no matter what genres they mostly like to watch. It's an anime that can be seen in a marathon mode or slowly slowly. You'll end up with a smile on your face anyway.

Season 1 of Non Non Biyori is a great show because the audience gets to watch how a country setting can nurture people and their relationships. 
The setting itself is a character in Non Non Biyori. It has a relationship with the characters and it helps them grow and develop. This is amplified by the minimalistic but beautiful art design that accompanies the show. The simple colors add to the personality of the setting, and beautiful backgrounds help give the audience an emotional core to latch onto. This allows for the audience to feel the same emotional connection to the setting as the characters. Thusallowing the drama of the narrative to be more immersive. \n
Then there is the characters themselves, who are simple yet enjoyable to watch. The shows narrative basically consists of situations that the setting puts them in. And what makes this narrative so compelling is the characters themselves. Each character has a very different personality that when clash together make for good television. Furthermore what makes this show so much better than other moe-girl shows is how the characters grow throughout the story. The characters grow by learning to face these situations that are presented to them. Each episode a character learns something about growing up or themselves. But the real crowning goal of Non Non Biyori’s story is the relationships of the characters. Without these very specific relationships that are made possible by the setting; the show would be no different from the usual moe fare. These relationships are great because each of them has a few specific quirks that work well with the other character’s quirks. It’s this perfect balance of quirks that makes them work so well. \n
There are other pieces of merit within Non Non Biyori as well.  For example, there is great comedic delivery given to us from visual presentation of the film. Great timing and shot composition give the comedy the spark that the show needs to stay entertaining. Furthermore the music of the show is very adorable and fitting, and it gives the show the tone and character it needs. \n
So overall Non Non Biyori gives the medium of anime a strong addition into the slice-of-life genre, and it is a show that can encourage other moe slice-of-life anime to properly use its setting and relationships to create an emotional core for the world presented in the show but also for the people watching.   \n

As a slice of life anime, the story is not anything spectacular. The show merely follows the lives of some kids living in the countryside. Seeing as this is true, the story is only mediocre because it is not the focus of the show. For someone looking for a gripping, inspiring slice of life, this will probably disappoint. 
But this show was not intended to have a stellar story, and it was still very enjoyable.
This show creates a very casual, comfortable atmosphere. The characters are generally relaxed, and the setting was depicted very well. It is easy to become immersed in the town the showis set in while watching. There are not any deep themes or hidden symbolic meanings that I could discern, but that does not mean the show was not good, it just did not have story depth.


The art style definitely enhanced some of the show's most amusing points. The appearance of the eyes is frequently changed to help represent various moods and build the atmosphere further. The eye artwork is definitely one of Non Non Biyori's strong points, and it is worth paying attention to while watching this show. There is nothing too spectacular nor bad about the art otherwise, but the little little things the artists do—such as use the appearance of the eyes—really add to the show's artistic appeal.


Music was another of the show's strong points. As I mentioned earlier, this show is very laid-back, and the soundtrack creates this feeling excellently. It has an original style—not orchestral nor like rock 'n' roll.One track follows the tune of "Row, Row, Row Your Boat" and it is only too fitting for this show. None of the humor is lewd, so the innocent humor of this show goes very well with the music used. On the other hand, none of the tracks will catch anyone's attention too well. They build the setting really well, but there are no tracks that are so good that I listen to them all the time. The OST's appeal comes from the way it builds the atmosphere through its original style. 


I do also like the show's OP too, but that might just be because I like nano.Ripe. The ED does use the voice actors, and it feels great hearing it after finishing an episode for all of the wonderful reasons that are too difficult to put into words. Natsumi and Renge's voice actors did a wonderful job. Natsumi's voice fit her character perfectly and added to the humor of all of her humorous scenes. Renge, being a first grader, was done flawlessly. These two voices were great in the ED as well and I absolutely loved the way they were done.


The characters were wonderful. Again, they go very well with the show's overall image. Renge, the 1st grader, is hilarious; filled with all the innocence and curiosity of a normal 1st grader, but adds to the comedic aspect of the show as much as any other character. All of the characters have very fitting appearances, too. After watching a few episodes, it is easy to catch onto the jokes made based on different characters because they are developed so well. 


Alongside Renge, Komari is another hilarious character. She is the center of many jokes throughout the series. I might even suggest that watching the show for these two characters is worth it. Even if you were to watch it solely for these two, it would be hard not to be captured by Hotaru and Natsumi as well because they are all done so well


The comedy of the show was great. For someone who has not watched a lot of anime or slice of life shows before, however, it will not be quite as enjoyable. Enjoyment does rely on the viewer's familiarity with Japanese culture to some extent. The characters are still enrolled in a school and are shown there somewhat often. Someone unfamiliar with the typical Japanese school setting will not find the show as enjoyable as someone who is familiar with it. When I watched this show, I had only watched a few school shows before and I still found it enjoyable. The jokes and scenes outside of the school setting are still prevalent and will make the show quite enjoyable even if you do not know all of the ins and outs of normal Japanese schools.


Overall, I thoroughly enjoyed this show. The countryside setting was very original, and it was built perfectly for being something so rarely done. Even with the lack of story depth this show was enjoyable because, as I said earlier, that was not the point of the show. It is one of my personal favorite slice of life/comedy shows. It's great character cast and innocent jokes make it difficult to not enjoy this show. The laid back atmosphere built wonderfully by the music places viewers in a relaxing world where they can enjoy watching this show. Though the lack of depth and slow pace may come off as bad things, Non Non Biyori's originality negates any negative effect because it makes them work. Do not let these things keep you from watching this show; it's originality actually does set it apart very well.

Looking for a innocent, calm, cute and charming anime that doesn't have overly sexualized children or women?
Look no further than Non Non Biyori...
This 12 episode beauty will leave you with a smile for sure, after ever episode, this relaxing anime, packs a punch with beautiful environment art, with a nonchalant feeling, as well as great Open intro and Ending music to set you in the mood.

Have you ever woken up one day, weary and drunk, realise you have to go to work or school, then just think: "What would life be like in the countryside?"
Non Non Biyori left a special mark on my heart, something that rarely happens in most of the SOL animes I have watched so far. At first glance, it looks really simple; 4 girls wandering about together, enjoying their lives and nothing special really happens. Or rather, that was what I thought before I began the first episode. And the first episode is the exact definition of a hook.
Let's break it down, shall we?
Story: 8/10
The plotof the anime focuses mainly on the everyday lives of the four girls, one of which is a Tokyo girl who is not used to the environment around her. If it was a normal show that had nothing special nor outstanding, I would have given it a 4. However, this show proved that it had what it took to go the extra mile, every episode giving yet a new conflict for the characters to solve and work around. Each new episode feels like a new adventure and personally, I felt part of the group and I enjoyed the sensation of the journey as much as they did. In terms of comedy, this show nailed it. Watching them screw up while on their journey really clogs your throat with amusement. Additionally, the cute faces (especially of Ren-chon and Komari-chan) never cease to make you smile. The comedy and the beautifully woven plot creates a heartwarming sensation burning in your heart after every episode, making you crave for the next.


Art: 9/10

Honestly, one look at the thumbnail and I already knew that the art was going to be great. It did not let me down at all. The series depicts beautiful landscapes of a thousand hues, warming your heart and making you wish you were there as well. The character designs were straight forward, yet wonderful in their own way. Their look changes according to the mood of the situation, like when Komari's face looks even cuter when she gets mad. The animators did an amazing job on this. The character movements were simple that it was nearly flawless. Poor art makes an anime unbearable to watch, no matter how great the plot is, but this anime shows exactly what Silver Link was capable of.


Sound: 9/10

This anime showcases 2 openings and 1 ending song, all of which were, in their own way, flawless. The first opening, Nanairo Biyori, displayed the childish yet fun theme of the show, catchy and adorable. The second opening, Kodama Kotodama, had a more country feel to it and my favourite soundtrack of the series. The fast pace of the song illustrates how fast time passes by in the story as well, not in a bad way of course. And Okaeri, the ending, was just cute and an amazing ending to an amazing episode.


Character: 9/10

Non Non Biyori displayed a vast diversity of different personalities for each character. For example, Ren-chon's quick understanding of every situation and Sugar Lady's sweet and caring side, masked behind that strict facade. Ultimately, no character is stuck with only one stereotypical characteristic.


Enjoyment: 10/10

No doubt, I loved it. Every second of it. According to Wittgenstein's Beetle-In-A-Box analogy, no matter how hard I try to describe the inordinate amount of happiness I felt while watching the show, no reader can understand its true potential without watching the show himself/herself.


Overall: 9/10

Alright, now the things I did not like about the show such that it missed that little point to make this anime flawless. This may contain spoilers!


I hated how they ended the story with a giant gaping hole, both in the main season and the OVA. How did life go on from there? It would be great if the last scene could feature one of the characters from like 3 years in the future, having a flashback on those times and sighing, before putting down the framed photograph and following the other 3 characters out for another exciting journey. The OVA ending was the most heartbreaking; what happened in Okinawa? Even the Repeat didn't cover that. But as time passes, I think that that gaping hole at the end of the series is what will keep me from forgetting Non Non Biyori.


Amazing anime, a must-watch for heartwarming anime lovers and Slice of Life lovers.

Couple of weeks ago, one of my friends from another website recommended this piece of fiction called Non Non Biyori. Everyday he would tell me go try the anime and I was telling him ''I will, don't worry ok!''. Now this review is for him. Gobb thank you for this amazing anime, love ya .
Story: 9/10
The story is very simple. You'll have your typical new transfer student introducing herself to her new teacher and friends. There's no plot. Just cute girls doing cute stuff. I'll talk more about the characters in the character section.
Art: 10/10
Yes! the art is a masterpiece. When I started watching thisanime. I thought I was watching fate unlimited blade works. Beautiful animation, characters and environment. 


Sound: 10/10


Let me give you a little bit of my background when it comes to sound. Most of the times I skip the opening and endings because they're nothing special. In this case, I never skipped the opening nor the ending. I watched the full 23 minutes in each episode. Is really that good. 


Character: 10/10


The characters are simply well written in my opinion. Hotaru is your typical waifu, kind of shy, female character. There's nothing wrong with her except the fact that she's overly attached to her senpai komari.


Komari and Natsumi have a pretty healthy relationship. They make jokes on each other from time to time, which I found hilarious. I was laughing in every episode that they were in with their jokes and how natsumi was teasing her big sister, even though natsumi on height is bigger than komari, but other than that, good sisters.


Last but not least, the best character of the show goes to Ren-chon. You simply cannot hate this character. There's no way! In every episode, I was hoping for her to get more panel time compared to hotaru and her friends. She's too cute and the things that she says are hilarious. I love her catchphrase (Nyan-pasu). It reminded me of rika from higurashi (Nipah!!). 


Enjoyment: 10/10


I had a blast watching this anime. I wasn't eager to watch this show but Gobb told me to, with a gun aiming at my head to watch it yes/yes or he might kidnap my cat, and it turned out to be GREAT! 


There was an episode that made me cry. Without spoiling here, I could relate to that character because It has happened to me in real life. So it made me sad because she was a little girl! She sat there for a minute and then started crying... manly tears were shed.


Overall: 10/10!


Sorry but this anime is a masterpiece in my book and I highly recommend it to the people looking for an amazing slice of life. Cute moments and relatable characters. Superb soundtrack and 10/10 animation. Can't go wrong with this anime.

This anime has a very calming effect. It reminds me of my younger days growing up in Philippines around the farm area. My favorite thing about this anime are the sound effects of the background nature is outstanding. It really captures how the country sounds like, from birds, to the wind, even the sound of the crickets!
As for the characters, it's funny but not TOO funny. As someone in their early 20s, the responsibilities of life are starting to be thrown at me, I found that some of the things the characters say and do would even have you reminiscing being a child and howeasy and effortless it was being young.
